content.rendered:
The ORGanizer, if you only have one extension, make it this one. The ORGanizer has so many awesome features and so much functionality, it’s hard to decide where to start. The extension is called the best Salesforce Extension EVER for a reason.  You can do so much with it, and it saves you so much time and effort. It’s really an amazing tool that you MUST have in your toolkit.

What it does

Login

 It so much, to give you an idea, here are some of the ways I use it everyday. First, it stores your login information. I’m not just talking about your username and password either. You know how you need to enter that activation code for some orgs? Well, with the ORGanizer, you can save your security token, allowing you to login WITHOUT your activation code. Talk about a fantastic start! 

Org Recognition

Next awesome feature, think about all those orgs you have, you have prod, sandboxes, dev orgs, if you are a consultant, numerous client orgs, you are probably rarely logged into one org at a time.  Enrico Murru, the creator of the ORGanizer, has included a way for you to keep all those orgs straight but just looking at your tabs. You can assign a color to each org, which is then shown on the cloud for each tab. Giving you easy visibility to each org, so you can easily find the org you need by sight, even if you can only see the cloud itself.

Login As

Now, I’ve previously talked about the LoginAs extension, well, that functionality has now been added to the ORGanizer, so you can login as any user with this extension as well. Just search for their name and BOOM! You can see what that user sees.

Field API Names

Now, when you are looking at a record, you see the label, but sometimes you need the API name for those fields. With the ORGanizer, you can easily switch what displays from the labels to the API names for easy access to your setup info from the record itself.

Quick Links

The ORGanizer as TONS of Quick Links built in.  Quick Links let you easily access setup information with a hotkey and the name of where you want to go, from anywhere.  No more having to click into setup!! Talk about a click saver.

Not everything you need to access over and over is a Quick Link already, no need to worry, you can make your own.  That’s right, records, reports, dashboards, whatever you regularly access can be saved as a custom Quick Link and accessed the exact same way. How do I use this? Great question, you may or may not know I specialize in Communities.

When doing testing, I have a set of contacts that are Community Users that I login to the Community as. I copy the link on the Contact for the “Login to Community as User” under the Manage User button.  Then I create a Quick Link with what I copied, and BOOM! I can login to the community as that user from anywhere. No more having to go to their contact, click Manage User, Click login to Community as User. It’s a HUGE time and click saver.  Quick Links are org specific, so you have the ability to make them for that ORG’s records

View all Fields

Sometimes you don’t have all the fields on the page layout. Especially useful if you are using that Login As feature and entering as an End User vs your Admin page layouts.  You can see what all the fields are for an object and that record’s values with the Sobject Fields functionality.

Org Describe

Maybe you want to know what all the objects in your org are, you can do that with the ORGanizer as well.  Just use the Org Description functionality, and all the objects will be listed for you.

15-18 Character ID

You can also switch 15 character IDs to 18 character.

Change Sets

One thing that’s always a pain is the creation and editing of Change Sets, the ORGanizer has simplified that.  First, you can export a package with all your metadata and a CSV of all the metadata in your change set. This makes your review of your change log easy.  You can also easily remove items from change sets without clicking Next, Next, Next, etc. for every single item you want to remove. You can just use the extension to search for the item in the change set, then click remove. HUGE time and click saver, like HUGE.

Games

Sometimes when you’re working hard, you deserve a break.  If you don’t take one, you’ll lose your mind.  The ORGanizer has planned for that too. You can play Cloud Invaders, right from the Extension.  It’s a lots of fun, but be careful, the close the invaders get to you the faster they go!

So that’s just some of the functionality the ORGanizer has, and there are updates and new features coming out on a consistent basis.  This extension, as I mentioned, is the brainchild of Enrico Murro, Salesforce MVP.  He takes in ideas from the Ohana and incorporates them in the extension in his free time.  He’s simply amazing, so just want to say THANK YOU Enrico for the best Salesforce Extension EVER!!

Cost

Free

Why I like it

First off, it lets you save your Username and Password for easy access to all your orgs, sandboxes, prod, pre-release, and dev orgs.  If you want, you can even save your Security Token for orgs that require you to activate. Allowing you to easily login without the access code.

You can setup your logins in the Extension from the icon

Then when you login, you have easy access to your usernames

By clicking the icon in your browser bar, you can login to your org without going to the login page. 

Once you are in your org, that’s where the awesomeness really starts….

You can use existing “Quick Links” to hop from one page to another in your org, reducing the number of clicks it takes you to get there. The link to login as Community Users, that’s HUGE for me.

In addition, with the ORGanizer @Add Option you can make custom hyperlinks to Salesforce URLs.  Just type in the CTRL+ L Hotkey to open the ORGanizer search bar, and type @add. Then type in the name for your bookmark.

Going forward, when you use the ORGanizer search bar hotkey, you will be able to access your new bookmark.

Easily accessing the List Views for objects that don’t have tabs is SUPER handy, I use that pretty much hourly.

The Org Describe is also awesome for getting your object prefix too.  Those first three characters of your record IDs, they tell you which object that record is. With the ORGanizer you can easily look it up.

Did I mention how much I love that I don’t have to go to the Developer Console to execute Anonymous Apex? Because I do!

I am also a BIG fan of being able to do queries from the ORGanizer to access data.  Awesome, every single day.

Also, I also love being able to see all the fields for an object, whether or not they are on the page layout.

As you can tell, I really do think very highly of this extension.  I said it before and I’ll say it again, if you are only going to have one Salesforce Extension, this is the one to get.

Why I dislike it

The only thing that drives me crazy, is that some weird zoom thing happened and I can’t seem to undo it. That is driving me nuts. I would like the extension window from the extension bar to go back to normal size.  I haven’t dug into it much though, so that is most likely user error some how.

Get the ORGanizer

ORGanizer in the Chrome Store

ORGanizer for FireFox

jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Presentation on tools extensions and apps for the Dallas Salesforce Developer User Group

jetpack-related-posts.title: LoginAs Beta
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: LoginAs is my best friend throughout the day.  It save me clicks & frustration.  I don't like going to find a user to login as them, even if I just search with the global search, LoginAs lets me select the user I want to LoginAs, debug, or both, from any page in SF. …

jetpack-related-posts.title: Salesforce Inspector
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: I love, love, love it! I love the Salesforce Inspector, I use it multiple times a day every single day, you can find the field requirements, field type, API names, export data, import data, and more!

jetpack-related-posts.title: Salesforce Advanced Code Searcher
jetpack-related-posts.excerpt: Sometimes you know the Apex Class or Visualforce page you need to go to, but to get there, ugg, Click Setup, Click Develop, Click Apex Classes, Letter S, Next Page, Next Page, Next Page, AHHH. Freakin’ can drive a dev or admin nuts, seriously.
